Posts.EditableText:
For your first point, Quest simply doesn't handle pronouns like other systems.

For the second, that's Quest working correctly.  "GET #BOOK#" will match any "get" command; in this case, "book" is just the name of the variable where it stores the matched text, and can refer to any object.  To do what you want, either create a command "GET BOOK", or add a "take" tag to the book, or possibly an "action <take>" tag.

The first is a problem with Quest. The second is you misusing Quest.

Whenever you use a command, the following code must handle _every_ input that matches it.

So the correct way to do it would be more like:

command <open #@item#> if (#item# = box) then {
 ... 
}
else if (#item# = closet) then {
 ...
}
else msg <You can't open that!>


OR

command <open #@item#> if action <#item#; open> then action <#item#; open>
else msg <You can't open that!>

and defining open actions on the appropriate box and closet

OR

command <open box; open cardboard box> ...
command <open closet; open door> ...

If your "read" command looks like "read #@object#" then you'll be able to use "read it".

You're misusing Quest, which is why you're having so much trouble.  (Probably you're trying too much to write things in the same way you'd write it in ADRIFT.)

1:  When you're writing commands, try giving the variables neutral names (so <smash #@noun#> instead of <smash #@drawer@>) to avoid internal preconceptions.

2:  Only the first command that matches will run.  It must handle any possible situation.

3:  Commands defined in <game> can run anywhere; unless you're designing a one-room game, the command given for <w> isn't what you want.

4:  As much as possible, try to put the interesting parts into actions instead of commands.

You'll find it easier to use verbs instead of commands for things like "smash drawer". If you go to your drawer object and add the verb "smash" to it, you can put your script in there.

This will automatically make "look at drawer" followed by "smash it" work, and it will give a sensible default response when the player tries to smash something else. And you won't have to worry about any variable names or any of that nasty "#@" stuff.

Also putting the bottle on the desk would be much more neatly handled if you set the desk up as a surface (on the Container tab in QDK).
